image.altText: Upwards shot of the BHP building in Perth.

items.synopsis: Mining giant BHP admits it has underpaid almost 30,000 workers, dating back to 2010, and it will cost more than $400 million to make amends.

title.children: 'Deeply sorry': Mining giant BHP admits underpaying almost 30,000 workers

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith dressed in a suit and tie

items.synopsis: Justice Anthony Besanko will soon say whether decorated war veteran Ben Roberts-Smith was defamed by news articles alleging he committed war crimes in Afghanistan. Follow live

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith to learn outcome of mammoth defamation battle

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Legal counsel for the Commonwealth has attempted to delay Justice Anthony Besanko from releasing his written judgement, according to Nine, who is a party in these proceedings. This is to ensure that redactions can be made to any of Justice Besanko's detailed reasonings, in case they disclose national security information. Ben Roberts-Smith's lawyers do not oppose the orders being sought, while the newspapers do. Justice Besanko will rule on the matter at 2.15pm today, when the judgement has been scheduled to be delivered.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Reports Commonwealth applies to delay judgement

children.content: Legal counsel for the Commonwealth has attempted
to delay

This is to ensure that
redactions
can be made to any of Justice Besanko's detailed reasonings, in case they disclose national security information.
Ben Roberts-Smith's lawyers do not oppose the orders being sought, while the newspapers do.
Justice Besanko will rule on the matter at
2.15pm today
, when the judgement has been scheduled to be delivered.

image.altText: Phil Egan looks stern standing near a river.

items.synopsis: Indigenous advocates have slammed the AFL's handling of the Hawthorn probe, and urged the league to become a "cultural leader" by addressing alleged mistreatment of First Nations players across the sporting code.

title.children: AFL urged to become 'cultural leader' amid fallout from Hawthorn probe

image.altText: Melbourne OPBD - POI 1

items.synopsis: Police say they are looking for two men who allegedly tricked a vulnerable passer-by into giving them his rent and pension money by pretending to tell his fortune.

title.children: Police launch appeal after vulnerable man conned out of $1,700 in fortune-telling scam

image.altText: The US Capitol's domed building against a grey sky with a lone US flag flying.

items.synopsis: Mining giant BHP has admitted to underpaying nearly 30,000 employees since 2010, while the ASX has opened lower as investors weigh the possibility of a rate hike. Follow live.

title.children: US House votes to suspend debt ceiling, ASX flat over interest rate concerns

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Mining and Energy Union has criticised BHP for underpaying its workers, saying have been "sprung ripping workers off". The MEU's general secretary Grahame Kelly says the union will ensure all affected members receive their full entitlements. "Today's revelation goes to show that we need to keep up the pressure on big companies like BHP to do the right thing," Mr Kelly said. "BHP has assumed that because they want round-the-clock profits from their mining operations, their workers aren't entitled to their public holiday rights. "We will make sure all our affected members receive every cent they are owed due to this stuff-up."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mining union says BHP has been 'sprung ripping workers off'

children.content: The Mining and Energy Union has criticised BHP for underpaying its workers, saying have been "sprung ripping workers off".
The MEU's general secretary Grahame Kelly says the union will ensure all affected members receive their full entitlements.
"Today's revelation goes to show that we need to keep up the pressure on big companies like BHP to do the right thing," Mr Kelly said.
"BHP has assumed that because they want round-the-clock profits from their mining operations, their workers aren't entitled to their public holiday rights.
"We will make sure all our affected members receive every cent they are owed due to this stuff-up."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Checking in on the Australian share market and the ASX200 is trending up at lunchtime after remaining flat for most of the morning. That boost can be largely attributed to the news out of the US that the debt ceiling has been suspended, meaning the US is one step closer to not defaulting next week. The bump has flowed through to most sectors, with consumer cyclicals and financials down -0.1% each, while the academic and educational services sector has taken a big hit, down -4.8%. The top five best performances as we approach 1pm include: Paladin Energy +11.0% Perseus Mining +4.7% De Grey Mining +4.5% Link Administration +3.9% Bellevue Gold +3.7% As for the worst five performers: Champion Iron -4.8% IDP Education -4.8% Alumina -4.1% Mineral Resources -3.5% Nickel Industries -2.8%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: After starting flat, the ASX has picked up thanks to the US debt ceiling suspension

children.content: Checking in on the Australian share market and the ASX200 is trending up at lunchtime after remaining flat for most of the morning.
That boost can be largely attributed to the news out of the US that the debt ceiling has been suspended, meaning the US is one step closer to not defaulting next week.
The bump has flowed through to most sectors, with consumer cyclicals and financials down -0.1% each, while the academic and educational services sector has taken a big hit, down -4.8%.
The top five best performances as we approach 1pm include:
Paladin Energy +11.0%
Perseus Mining +4.7%
De Grey Mining +4.5%
Link Administration +3.9%
Bellevue Gold +3.7%
As for the worst five performers:
Champion Iron -4.8%
IDP Education -4.8%
Alumina -4.1%
Mineral Resources -3.5%
Nickel Industries -2.8%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's a fair question. In essence, the legislation temporarily removes the US government's borrowing limit until January 1, 2025. But the suspension of the debt ceiling came with a cap on some government spending over the next two years, speed up the permitting process for some energy projects, and claw back its unused COVID-19 funds. Despite the bipartisan support in the House, some Republicans wanted the spending cuts to go deeper. One thing to note with the suspension's end date — it means Biden and Congress can set aside the potentially risky issue of the debt ceiling until after the next presidential election in November 2024.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What does suspending the US debt ceiling mean?

children.content: It's a fair question. In essence, the legislation temporarily removes the US government's borrowing limit until January 1, 2025.

But the suspension of the debt ceiling came with a cap on some government spending over the next two years, speed up the permitting process for some energy projects, and claw back its unused COVID-19 funds.
Despite the bipartisan support in the House,
some Republicans wanted the spending cuts to go deeper.

One thing to note with the suspension's end date — it means Biden and Congress can set aside the potentially risky issue of the debt ceiling until after the next presidential election in November 2024.
